captions.text:
If you know the explanation for why the sky's
blue, you've heard that sunlight is white

light composed of many frequencies and that
higher frequency, bluer, light scatters in

the air more than lower frequency, redder,
light. So, you might ask "why isn't the sky

violet, since violet is an even higher frequency
than blue?". First off, ultraviolet light

and x-rays are also higher frequency than
blue, and that doesn't mean the sky is the

color of x-rays… Both because we can't see
them and also because the sun doesn't make

very many of them and then the atmosphere
blocks them all - which is probably why we

didn't evolve to be able to see them. And
secondly, the color violet in the rainbow

is the "roses are red, violets are BLUE" violet.
Not purple – it's dark blue.

To see why, check out this Chromaticity Diagram!
It's a graph of all possible colors as perceived

by non-colorblind humans, ignoring brightness
and context. The color displayed on the diagram

is just to give you a rough idea – unfortunately
your computer can't display all possible perceived

colors – it can just display the ones inside
a triangle like this, and is pretending for
the rest.

Single frequency light like that from a laser
or from splitting white light into a rainbow

is graphed around this outside edge, while
any color anywhere on the inside or along

the bottom edge can only be made with a combination
of various frequencies of light. As you can

see, pink, purple and magenta can only be
made using multiple frequencies of light - there

is no single frequency of light that's pink
- and of course, white light is a mixture

as well! Which is why you don't see any of
these colors in rainbows made from prisms.

But back to the Chromaticity diagram! See
this line in the middle? This shows what color

hot objects glow - we have red hot, then white
hot, then blue hot. All of these "hot" colors

are made up of a broad range of frequencies,
since that's what hot objects emit. The sun,

for example, is white hot before it hits the
atmosphere, then its light is split by scattering

off of air molecules so the sun looks slightly
red hot and the rest of the sky looks kind
of blue hot. Like this picture of a sunset!

And the thing is this - if you notice the
line for hot-object color, well, it stops

in the middle of the diagram near whitish-blue.
It never goes beyond that. And that's because

the spectrum of light from an object hotter
than the sun always has a decreasing tail,

with slightly more blue than green than red,
so you never get the right combination of

frequencies to push the color towards purple,
or for that matter, even towards a pure, deep
violet blue.

Kind of like how you can mix flour and water
in different ratios to make bread, pancakes,

or vegetarian gravy, but as long as you have
flour in there, your gravy won't be gluten
free.

And that's why the sky appears blueish white.
It's basically gravy.

+jampk24 Because the video is wrong, monochromatic light of that wavelength 
appears distinctly reddish blue to colour-normal observers, it's only even 
redder purples that can only be formed by mixing. The mistake may spring 
from the fact that spectral violet appears blue in digital photos because 
it only affects the blue sensor of the camera.

comments.author: Brandon Tollison

comments.text:
Spectral violet consists of single wavelengths that create a combination of 
red and blue perceptions in the human visual system. However in a digital 
camera these wavelengths only affect the short wavelength (Blue) sensor and 
not the long wavelength (Red) one, so they photograph as deep blue. I don't 
know why anyone would say that spectral violet is actually a deep blue 
unless they need to look at a real spectrum instead of relying on photos.﻿

comments.author: Maximum Frequency (SkyLight585)

comments.text:
+Maximum Frequency /Of course I can figure it out/

Then do so.  That way you'll be able to refine your question(s).

Unless what you really want is for someone else to do your work for you.

/but I want a precise answer/

Precise answers from scientists require precise questions, and "a giant 
cloud" just... isn't.

1) How at what altitude does the cloud appear?
2) How many meters thick is the cloud?
3) How hot is the cloud?
4) What's the weather like?
5) Would the fluorine *replace* or *displace* the air?
6) Fluorine atoms or fluorine molecules (Fl2)?

/How would it look?/

From the Westchester or Manhattan?

/Would buildings actually explode/
/or would they just catch fire?/

WTF gives you the idea that concrete would *explode* when exposed to 
fluorine???

http://www.webelements.com/fluorine/chemistry.html
comments.author: RonJohn63

comments.text:
+RonJohn63 Of course I can figure it out, but I want a precise answer from 
someone who is a bona fide chemist/physicist, not just an enthusiast like 
me (unless they know the answer. I want details: How would it look? Would 
buildings actually explode, or would they just catch fire? What exactly 
would explode or catch fire and what would remain chemically inert? would 
peoples' skin catch fire? what about their eyes? would the fluorine 
eventually disintegrate their entire bodies? Details.

comments.author: IamGrimalkin

comments.text:
+OTNCBC
Point taken. In class, a few weeks back, I was fairly happy with estimating 
the density of a nucleus to within three orders of magnitude. Still a 
thousand times out but at least I wasn't 10^23 times out, like one of my 
classmates.
comments.author: blinkyrem

comments.text:
A valid point, however the adjective "astronomical" has a reason for its 
meaning. 
1hour-1 month, or year is a few orders of magnitude, but when a star weighs 
10^30 kg, and your estimate is 10^28kg, a physicist will tell you that's a 
good effort. 
Numbers in space get silly quickly, distances, masses, densities etc have 
magnitudes unimaginably different than you see in every day objects.
At these scales, a few orders of magnitude can be forgiven (at least by me, 
anyway)
comments.author: OTNCBC

comments.text:
Ah fair enough, although a couple of orders is still a fair amount of 
change. (1 hour -> 25.5 days or 1 hour -> 700 years)

Huzzah for artistic license otherwise all films would just be real life!
comments.author: blinkyrem

comments.text:
I haven't done the numbers either, but having completed a physics degree, I 
can guesstimate that as long as you're orbiting a black hole (i.e. in the 
near vicinity, not far away like Earth from the galactic central black 
hole), time dilation will probably be within a few orders of the amount 
shown in the film. 
At that point, you're allowed artistic license to say its a little 
more/less than the true value :)
comments.author: OTNCBC

comments.text:
I'm not too sure of the numbers though, as I haven't/can't yet do the 
calculations to verify them. (applying for Physics at university so maybe 
in a few years) For all I know, such time dilation might only occur within 
say the event horizon of the black hole and an orbiting planet would be 
pretty much unnaffected.
comments.author: blinkyrem

comments.text:
+blinkyrem Having read some of the plot on wikipedia, it starts to make 
sense.
If the planet was orbiting a black hole, the plot seems fine to me. From 
the other guy's comment, it seemed like he was suggesting a 30% mass 
increase caused that huge time dilation effect.
Now, I can rest easy - the plot is at least somewhat thought out by the 
looks of it, I can rest easy ^^
comments.author: OTNCBC

comments.text:
As with most science fiction, the concepts are correct in theory and a 
situation can be found where it is correct in practice but it's bloody hard 
to find a situation that's correct and also works for the story. So there 
comes a point where they just have to fudge it.

In Interstellar, the Black Hole could have caused such time dilation but 
the problem is that the guy in orbit around the planet would have been aged 
pretty much the same as the guys on the planet so... I found the fudge 
factor.
comments.author: blinkyrem

comments.text:
Although on the planet with 136% the gravity of earth, 1 hr wouldn't be

It's all to do with relativity. Although I'm not entirely sure of the 
details so anyone correct me if I'm wrong :)

comments.author: Peter Smythe

comments.text:
Of course, sunlight doesn't emit a lot of violet, and the air attenuates it 
further, as do most other "transparent" materials. Anything that reflected 
pure violet but not red would probably end up looking very dark, both 
because our eyes don't perceive it very well, and there just aren't that 
many violet photons flying around under normal conditions to reflect into 
our eyes. In reality, most violet dyes are actually purple.


On the other hand, take this image of a rainbow, from Wikipedia:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainbow#mediaviewer/File:WhereRainbowRises.jpg

Or this image, also from wiki, of the emission spectrum of a black light.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_light#mediaviewer/File:Fluorescent_Black-Light_spectrum_with_peaks_labelled.gif


Now, if we look at a black light, it is obviously violet, no question, and 
yet, it emits no red light? How can this be? Because violet doesn't 
actually look blue, it looks purple (ish).﻿
comments.author: Peter Smythe

comments.text:
Except that you do see violet in prismatic rainbows. Look at the image 
there? Given, you see purple, not violet, but it's there.﻿
comments.author: Peter Smythe

comments.text:
Uh.... violet does actually exist as a frequency of light. Purple-looking 
violet.
Anyone who's tried putting a royal blue LED in liquid nitrogen knows this.

Or for that matter, anyone who owns a 380–450 nm actual violet LED. They 
look purple, and the reflections off of white objects look REALLY purple. 
They aren't purple, they are violet, but they look that way. It is actually 
not possible to reproduce real violet on a computer monitor, despite it 
taking up 25.4% of the logarithmic size of the human visual range. (380-740 
nm).

That's almost as big as red. Much larger than orange and yellow combined, 
larger than green, larger than blue, larger than blue or green including 
cyan. It's the second-largest part of the visual spectrum to have a name 
for the color, and yet you deny it exists?﻿
comments.author: Peter Smythe
